pages.text: Wood is not the most efficient fuel. It burns for enough for most recipes, but intensive burning can leave you without logs very quickly.

pages.title: Fire Pellets
pages.text: $(thing)Fire Pellets$() are a much more efficient fuel, that burns for about as much as a log, but for about half the cost.

pages.title: Grinding Lumber
pages.text: You can turn your lumber into $(thing)Fire Pellets$() using a $(l:mechanics/quern)Quern$(). This powder is not ready to burn, it needs to be compressed first. Thatch is another, less efficient way to get it. If you can get Bark or Bast, you can grind that too! Sawdust is ready to use to make pellets.
Compressing the powder gives you a group of $(thing)Fire Pellets$(), that burn as much as a Maple Log.

Compressing those pellets further using some glue will give you $(thing)Firelogs$(). They burn for 5 times as long as the pellets they are made of, and can be used as logs in the $(l:getting_started/pit_kiln)Pit Kiln$(), and even stored in log piles!
You can turn bamboo into $(thing)Fire Pellets$() too! However, they burn for about half the time as regular pellets.

Most logs need to be turned to lumber to be ground up. Exception is the $(thing)Palm Log$(). Due to being much more efficient and caloric than regular wood, it is better to convert these logs directly to fibers. If you can get Bark or Bast, you can grind that too!

Please be careful, as palm fibers are only extracted from the log, not the palm lumber. As such, if you want the $(thing)Palm Fire Pellets$(), grind the log and not the lumber!. They are worth it, as they burn 3 times more than the log itself, up to 15 minutes in its firelog! They burn at a lower temperature, though.
